& enter the temporo-sphenoidal lobe joining with 
the fibres of the anterior commissure in its 
distribution to this part of the brain.
[A third set of <s>fibres <\s> these descending fibres of the 
outer capsule passes obliquely backwards to the 
posterior end of the lenticular nucleus, runs through 
the lenticular nucleus & in part joins the inner capsule 
posteriorly, in part sends a large number of fibres 
into the optic tract at the part where it lies over 
the crus cerebri. The subject of the composition & 
connections of the capsule, however, would 
require special & detailed description to make 
it thoroughly intelligible <s>understood <\s>. I am persuaded that 
the outer capsule is a far more important 
structure than is generally supposed acting as 
it does as a means of connecting the olfactory & optic nerves 
& the <s>hearing <\s> auditory centre in the temporo-sphenoidal lobe 
with the cerebral cortex of the opposite side. The 
subject is however much too extensive & important to take up a part 
of the present communication.
